description:
Dasyurus viverrinus, commonly known as the eastern quoll, is a small to medium-sized carnivorous marsupial native to Tasmania and southeastern Australia. It belongs to the family Dasyuridae, which includes other quolls, Tasmanian devils, and numbats.

The eastern quoll has a distinctive black and white spotted coat, with a slender, muscular body and a long, pointed snout. It is a nocturnal and arboreal species, spending much of its time in trees and shrubs, but also foraging on the ground. Its diet consists primarily of small mammals, birds, reptiles, and insects.

Dasyurus viverrinus is a solitary and territorial species, with males and females occupying separate home ranges. Females give birth to a litter of up to six young, which they carry in their pouch for about two months before the young emerge and begin to forage independently.

The eastern quoll is considered a threatened species due to a variety of factors, including habitat loss, predation by introduced species (such as foxes and cats), and disease outbreaks. Conservation efforts are underway to protect and recover this unique Australian marsupial.
